title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: At the time of this first visit to Edinburgh, my sister was boarded with Miss Hall, 13 Great King Street, and my uncle and aunt Henderson also were residing, for the education of their family, in the house 15 Gayfield Square. They had taken lodgings for us in No. 6 St James Street, on the first flat.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Mr. Mackenzie's wife's aunt, Mrs. Walrond, of Calder Park, (maiden name, Jane Hastings), was at Miss Hall's boarding-school in Edinburgh with Jane Welsh. * Miss Hall's,* writes Mr. Mackenzie, *was a well-known school, latterly in Great King Street; but as that street could scarcely have been built before 1820, it must have been elsewhere before that.* Here is one little point in Jane Welsh's history fortunately cleared up. Evidently Mrs. Welsh had been anxious that her brilliant daughter should have what was then termed a '■finishing^ — an opportunity, namely, of acquiring certain feminine accomplishments and elegances not easily attainable in the Haddington school, yet needful to blend with the rather masculine education she had already received.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: " We can come back here for the winter, or go to Cairo. What do you say to Cairo, Francis ? " " I would rather say Great King Street, Edinburgh, Papa, and back to college." " Well, of course, you have both missed a session, but health is of more importance."

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: " The money, Lucy ; some girls would marry his satanic majesty for money ! And that brings me to this other letter, which is about your money that is to be, Lucy. This is from Mr. Beaumont in Great King Street, informing me that the will is ready for my signature, and wishing us—you and I — to go there and have it signed; or if more convenient to me, he will send it here. Now, which course do you think I should take ? " " How many people require to sign the paper, Aunt ? " inquires Lucy.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,

Poor little fellow ! It might soften a very hard heart to see him so courteous, yet so weak and poor, totter ing /tome with his two children to a miserable lodg ing-house, and writing all day for that prince of donkeys, the proprietor of ' The Saturday Post.' " De Quincey lived in Great King Street, in Forres Street, and at Duddingston ; later he lodged at 42 Lothian Street, "in the left-hand flat on the second floor." This is one of the few houses in Edinburgh considered worthy of a label, a tablet upon it re cording the fact that it was once De Quincey's home.

title: My college days,

snippet: Another family to whose intimacy I was freely admitted was that of J. Shank More, and to them and himself I was indebted for many kind hospitalities. Mr. More was an eminent advocate of Edinburgh, and lived, with his wifc^, two grown-up sons, and several daughters, in a handsome residence in Great King Street. I met the best of company at their house, chiefly the distinguished professional men of Edinburgh and their families.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

From the window, yes, there was the railing and the flight of steps she had walked up ; well, she would just walk down again and go home at once.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: Bureau, desks, drawers, wardrobes, every place that opened with a key, they busily ransacked, seeking for anything in the form of a Will, but no such document could they find. Letters were found from Lucy, from themselves, and from Mr. Beaumont, Great King Street.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: So they parted, Williams to London, Francis another day's journey ere he reached Edinburgh. Having arrived at his home in Great King Street he found his parents well; but they at once perceived there was something amiss with him, and as Mr. Beaumont had by this time been informed of Mrs. Stewart's death, explanations followed; but where Lucy could have gone was a mystery to all. Before setting out on his search next morning Francis received a telegram from Williams: "Address not known."

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

title: St. Andrews and elsewhere;

title: St. Andrews and elsewhere;

snippet: But none ever knew him well without loving him. I do remember one individual, quite extraordinarily ordinary, whom I foolishly (at his own request) brought into my dwelling in Great King Street when Froude was with us in his first visit to Edinburgh, and indeed to Scotland. I see him yet sitting by the drawing-room fire that afternoon, critically estimating the historian ; and indeed putting him to the proof by some remarks as to the standards of the Kirk.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: Mrs. Chalmers and ray faraily share with me in a sorrow which must well-nigh overwhelm yourself, but which, I earnestly pray, may be soothed and sanctified by the God of all comfort. My daughter Anne was particularly solem nized by the recency of our visit, and her recollections of all the kindness that we had gotten under your roof The walk from Great King Street to the Register Office is powerfully and touchingly present to both our rainds ; nor do I remem ber, in the whole compass of ray experience, a more impress ive manifestation of God's mysterious sovereignty, and of man's duty to be humble, and watchful, and mindful of death.

title: Later letters of Marcus Dods, D. D. (late principal of New college, Edinburgh) (1895-1909)
author: Dods, Marcus
snippet: My very dear Grand-daughter Edith Marcia Gray, — I, Marcus Dods, of 23 Great King Street, Edinburgh, humbly apologise for not sending you any present on your birthday. It was indeed bad of me, for I am very very glad you were born (where would you be if you had not been born ? Ask Jessie to tell you, for I can't), and I am sure a great many people will be glad, for you are going to make a lot of people happy, are you not ? And do you know the best way to make people happy ? It is to be happy yourself.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: I shall not go in, for, after all, what good can it do ? These harrowing tales must be repeated with each new face I see to talk to, and only tear open the wound afresh." She was so ghastly on returning that Mary's heart bled for her, but she said nothing, and after tea they both drove to Great King Street. It was quite dark, so they agreed that Mary should wait in the cab at the corner of the street, while Lucy wrent her hopeless quest alone.

I heard that she had been down in Great King Street recently." " Did you ? She told me she was going there a short time ago; and she wishes me to go there with her another time—though I don't know the reason."

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

snippet: And so he was. In his own room in Great King Street, he was standing with the portrait in his hand, as if he could look for ever on the dear face ; and the note she had written—how often he read and re-read those precious words, and at last went to sleep with both gifts under his pillow smiling and dreaming of her all the night long, too !

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc

snippet: Bella put down her hand and lifted the first one. "Jist let me shak' this oot an' hang't up for ye," she said, " it'll be a-crushed there, siccan a bonnie silk ! " It was the dress Lucy wore the day she was at Great King Street. " Another ane ! " said Bella, hanging it up also.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: Mary had read the fatal list, and knowing of Lucy's recent encounter with Mr. Haiton, knew now the cause of her silent grief. Lucy waited until the evening before going to Great King Street, having resolved to go there before seeking Mr. Haiton. She went alone, slowly along the street, a subtle sense of chill and fear overpowering her, and stopped at the house wherein she had once spent happy hours ; few, short-lived like her hopes, and now so far away—all seemed a delusive vision of long ago.

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
